Appendix A. The Dirichlet Process

The formal definition of the Dirichlet process is as follows. Let (𝒳,Ω)𝒳Ω(\mathcal{X},\Omega) be a measurable space and let μ𝜇\mu be a measure (unnormalized density) on this space that is finite, additive, non-negative and non-null. We say that a random probability measure Pμsuperscript𝑃𝜇P^{\mu} on (𝒳,Ω)𝒳Ω(\mathcal{X},\Omega) is a Dirichlet process with parameter μ𝜇\mu under the following condition: whenever {B1,…,BK}subscript𝐵1…subscript𝐵𝐾\{B_{1},\dots,B_{K}\} is a measurable partition of ΩΩ\Omega (i.e., each μ​(Bk)>0𝜇subscript𝐵𝑘0\mu(B_{k})>0 for all k𝑘k) , then the joint distribution of random probabilities (Pμ​(B1),…,Pμ​(BK))superscript𝑃𝜇subscript𝐵1…superscript𝑃𝜇subscript𝐵𝐾(P^{\mu}(B_{1}),\dots,P^{\mu}(B_{K})) is distributed according to 𝒟​ir​(μ​(B1),…,μ​(BK))𝒟ir𝜇subscript𝐵1…𝜇subscript𝐵𝐾\mathcal{D}\textit{ir}(\mu(B_{1}),\dots,\mu(B_{K})), where 𝒟​ir𝒟ir\mathcal{D}\textit{ir} denotes the standard Dirichlet distribution (Ferguson, 1973, 1974). In words: Pμsuperscript𝑃𝜇P^{\mu} is a Dirichlet process if it behaves as if it were a Dirichlet distribution on any finite partition of the original space.

It is typically useful to write μ=α​G0𝜇𝛼subscript𝐺0\mu=\alpha G_{0}, where α=∫Ωd​μ𝛼subscriptΩd𝜇\alpha=\int_{\Omega}\textrm{d}\mu and G0=μ/αsubscript𝐺0𝜇𝛼G_{0}=\mu/\alpha, so that G0subscript𝐺0G_{0} is a density. In this case we refer to G0subscript𝐺0G_{0} as the base distribution or the mean distribution of the DP, and α𝛼\alpha as the precision, or scale parameter.

Two fundamental results regarding the DP that are important to us are: (1) observations from a DP are discrete (with probability one) and (2) if Pμsuperscript𝑃𝜇P^{\mu} is a DP with parameter μ𝜇\mu, then the conditional distribution of Pμsuperscript𝑃𝜇P^{\mu} given a sample X1,…,XNsubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑁X_{1},\dots,X_{N} is a DP with parameter Pμ+∑n=1NδXnsuperscript𝑃𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛿subscript𝑋𝑛P^{\mu}+\sum_{n=1}^{N}\delta_{X_{n}}, where δXsubscript𝛿𝑋\delta_{X} is a point mass concentrated at X𝑋X (Ferguson, 1974). The final useful fact is a correspondence between the DP and Pòlya Urns, described by Blackwell and MacQueen (1973). In the Pòlya Urn construction, we consider the situation of an urn from which we draw balls. Initially the urn contains a single black ball. At any time step, we draw a ball x𝑥x from the urn. If x𝑥x is black (as it must be on the first draw), we put x𝑥x back into the urn and also add a ball of a brand new color. If x𝑥x was not black, we put x𝑥x back into the urn and also put in an additional ball of the same color. The pattern of draws from such an urn describes draws from a DP (with α=1𝛼1\alpha=1). In this scheme, we can see that there is a clustering effect in this model: as more balls of one color (say, blue) are drawn, the number of blue balls in the urn increases, so the probability of drawing a blue ball in the next iteration is higher. However, regardless of how many balls there are in the urn, there is always some probability the black ball (i.e., a ball of a new color) is drawn. This relative probability is controlled by the precision parameter α𝛼\alpha. For low α𝛼\alpha, there will be few colors and for high α𝛼\alpha, there will be many colors. The appropriateness of such a prior depends on one’s prior intuitions about the problem; more flexible similar priors are given in terms of exchangeable probability partition functions, including a simple two-parameter extension of the DP, by Pitman (1996).

As noted by Ferguson (1983), the discreteness of observations from the DP means that observations from the distributions drawn from a DP can be viewed as countably infinite mixtures. This can be seen directly by considering a model that first draws a distribution G𝐺G from a DP with parameter α​G0𝛼subscript𝐺0\alpha G_{0} and then draws observations θ1,…subscript𝜃1…\theta_{1},\dots from G𝐺G. In such a model, one can analytically integrate out G𝐺G to obtain the following conditional distributions from the observations θnsubscript𝜃𝑛\theta_{n} (Blackwell and MacQueen, 1973; Ferguson, 1983):

θn+1​ | ​θ1,…,θn∼αn+α​G0+1n+α​∑i=1nδθisimilar-toconditionalsubscript𝜃𝑛1  subscript𝜃1…subscript𝜃𝑛𝛼𝑛𝛼subscript𝐺01𝑛𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝛿subscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{n+1}\textrm{~{}}\arrowvert\textrm{~{}}\theta_{1},\dots,\theta_{n}~{}\sim~{}\frac{\alpha}{n+\alpha}~{}G_{0}+\frac{1}{n+\alpha}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\delta_{\theta_{i}}

Thus, the n+1𝑛1n+1st data point is drawn with probability proportional to α𝛼\alpha from the base distribution G0subscript𝐺0G_{0}, and is exactly equal to a previously drawn θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} with probability proportional to ∑j=1nδθi=θjsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝛿subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝜃𝑗\sum_{j=1}^{n}\delta_{\theta_{i}=\theta_{j}}. This characterization leads to a straightforward implementation of a Gibbs sampler. It also enables one to show that the posterior density of a DP with parameter μ𝜇\mu after observing N𝑁N observations θ1,…,θNsubscript𝜃1…subscript𝜃𝑁\theta_{1},\dots,\theta_{N} is again a DP with parameter μ+∑n=1Nδθn𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛿subscript𝜃𝑛\mu+\sum_{n=1}^{N}\delta_{\theta_{n}} (Ferguson, 1973).

Appendix B. Sampling the Precision Parameter

West (1992) describes a method of sampling the precision parameter α𝛼\alpha for a DP mixture model. Placing a 𝒢​am​(a,b)𝒢am𝑎𝑏\mathcal{G}\textit{am}(a,b) prior over α𝛼\alpha, when n𝑛n (the number of observations) and k𝑘k (the number of unique mixture components) are known, one first samples an intermediary value x𝑥x by a beta distribution xα​(1−x)n−1superscript𝑥𝛼superscript1𝑥𝑛1x^{\alpha}(1-x)^{n-1}, where α𝛼\alpha is the previous value for the precision parameter. Given this random variable x𝑥x, one resamples α𝛼\alpha according to a mixture of two Gamma densities:

πx​𝒢​am​(a+k,b−log⁡x)+(1−πx)​𝒢​am​(a+k−1,b−log⁡x)subscript𝜋𝑥𝒢am𝑎𝑘𝑏𝑥1subscript𝜋𝑥𝒢am𝑎𝑘1𝑏𝑥\pi_{x}\mathcal{G}\textit{am}(a+k,b-\log x)+(1-\pi_{x})\mathcal{G}\textit{am}(a+k-1,b-\log x)

Where πxsubscript𝜋𝑥\pi_{x} is the solution to πx/(1−πx)=(a+k−1)/[n​(b−log⁡x)]subscript𝜋𝑥1subscript𝜋𝑥𝑎𝑘1delimited-[]𝑛𝑏𝑥\pi_{x}/(1-\pi_{x})=(a+k-1)/[n(b-\log x)]. To extend this method to the case with multiple n𝑛n and k𝑘k, we first recall the result of Antoniak (1974), which states that the prior distribution of k𝑘k given α𝛼\alpha and n𝑛n is given by:

p​(k​ | ​α,n)=cn​(k)​n!​αk​Γ​(α)Γ​(α+n)𝑝conditional𝑘  𝛼𝑛subscript𝑐𝑛𝑘𝑛superscript𝛼𝑘Γ𝛼Γ𝛼𝑛p\left({k}\textrm{~{}}\arrowvert\textrm{~{}}\alpha,{n}\right)=c_{n}({k}){n}!\alpha^{k}\frac{\Gamma(\alpha)}{\Gamma(\alpha+{n})}

Here, cn​(k)∝|Sn(k)|proportional-tosubscript𝑐𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑛𝑘c_{n}(k)\propto|S_{n}^{(k)}|, a Stirling number of the first kind, does not depend on α𝛼\alpha. Placing a gamma prior on α𝛼\alpha with shape parameter a𝑎a and scale parameter b𝑏b, we obtain the posterior distribution of α𝛼\alpha given all the nm,kmsubscript𝑛𝑚subscript𝑘𝑚n_{m},k_{m} as:

p​(α​ | ​𝒙,𝒌,𝒏)𝑝conditional𝛼  𝒙𝒌𝒏\displaystyle p\left(\alpha\textrm{~{}}\arrowvert\textrm{~{}}\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{k},\boldsymbol{n}\right) ∝proportional-to\displaystyle\propto e−b​α​αa−1​∏m=1Mαkm−1​(α+nm)​xmα​(1−xm)nm−1superscript𝑒𝑏𝛼superscript𝛼𝑎1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑚1𝑀superscript𝛼subscript𝑘𝑚1𝛼subscript𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑚𝛼superscript1subscript𝑥𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚1\displaystyle e^{-b\alpha}\alpha^{a-1}\prod_{m=1}^{M}\alpha^{k_{m}-1}(\alpha+n_{m})x_{m}^{\alpha}(1-x_{m})^{n_{m}-1} (4)
∝proportional-to\displaystyle\propto αa−M−1+∑m=1Mkm​e−α​(b−log​∏m=1Mxm)​∏m=1M(α+nm)superscript𝛼𝑎𝑀1superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑘𝑚superscript𝑒𝛼𝑏superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑥𝑚superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑚1𝑀𝛼subscript𝑛𝑚\displaystyle\alpha^{a-M-1+\sum_{m=1}^{M}k_{m}}e^{-\alpha\left(b-\log\prod_{m=1}^{M}x_{m}\right)}\prod_{m=1}^{M}(\alpha+n_{m})

The product in Eq (4) can be written as the sum over a vector of binary indicator variables 𝒊𝒊\boldsymbol{i} of length M𝑀M, which gives us:

α​ | ​𝒙,𝒌,𝒏∼∑𝒊∈2Mρ𝒊​𝒢​am​(a−M+∑m=1Mkm+im,b−log​∏m=1Mxm)similar-toconditional𝛼  𝒙𝒌𝒏subscript𝒊superscript2𝑀subscript𝜌𝒊𝒢am𝑎𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑘𝑚subscript𝑖𝑚𝑏superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑥𝑚\alpha\textrm{~{}}\arrowvert\textrm{~{}}\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{k},\boldsymbol{n}\sim\sum_{\boldsymbol{i}\in 2^{M}}\rho_{\boldsymbol{i}}\mathcal{G}\textit{am}\left(a-M+\sum_{m=1}^{M}k_{m}+i_{m},b-\log\prod_{m=1}^{M}x_{m}\right) (5)

Where, writing a^^𝑎\hat{a} to denote the value a−M−1+∑m=1Mkm𝑎𝑀1superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑘𝑚a-M-1+\sum_{m=1}^{M}k_{m} and b^^𝑏\hat{b} to denote b−log​∏m=1Mxm𝑏superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑥𝑚b-\log\prod_{m=1}^{M}x_{m}, the mixing weights 𝝆𝝆\boldsymbol{\rho} are defined by:

ρ𝒊=1Z​Γ​(a^+∑m=1Mim)​∏m=1M(nm​b^)1−imsubscript𝜌𝒊1𝑍Γ^𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝑖𝑚superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑚1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚^𝑏1subscript𝑖𝑚\rho_{\boldsymbol{i}}=\frac{1}{Z}\Gamma\left(\hat{a}+\sum_{m=1}^{M}i_{m}\right)\prod_{m=1}^{M}\left(n_{m}\hat{b}\right)^{1-i_{m}} (6)

To see the correctness of this derivation, consider a given 𝒊𝒊\boldsymbol{i}. There are ∑imsubscript𝑖𝑚\sum i_{m} choices of α𝛼\alpha, corresponding to the ∑imsubscript𝑖𝑚\sum i_{m} in the shape parameter for the posterior gamma distribution in Eq (5). For each of these, the constant from the gamma distribution is decreased by a factor of Γ​(a^+∑im)/Γ​(a^)Γ^𝑎subscript𝑖𝑚Γ^𝑎\Gamma(\hat{a}+\sum i_{m})/\Gamma(\hat{a}); compensating for this results in the first term above (with the bottom half omitted since it is just a constant). Additionally, each term for which im=0subscript𝑖𝑚0i_{m}=0 means that nmsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m} was chosen (instead of α𝛼\alpha), so a factor of nm=nm1−imsubscript𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚1subscript𝑖𝑚n_{m}=n_{m}^{1-i_{m}} needs to be included. Finally, when the shape parameter of the gamma distribution increases by 111 for each im=1subscript𝑖𝑚1i_{m}=1, the constant of proportionality for the gamma distribution increases by a factor of b−log​∏xm𝑏productsubscript𝑥𝑚b-\log\prod x_{m}, which is compensated for by the last term above.

Similarly, we can obtain a marginal distribution for each xmsubscript𝑥𝑚x_{m} conditional on α𝛼\alpha and k𝑘k as:

xm​ | ​α,nm,km∝xmα​(1−xm)nm−1∼ℬ​et​(α+1,nm)proportional-toconditionalsubscript𝑥𝑚  𝛼subscript𝑛𝑚subscript𝑘𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑚𝛼superscript1subscript𝑥𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚1similar-toℬet𝛼1subscript𝑛𝑚x_{m}\textrm{~{}}\arrowvert\textrm{~{}}\alpha,n_{m},k_{m}~{}~{}\propto~{}~{}x_{m}^{\alpha}(1-x_{m})^{n_{m}-1}~{}~{}\sim~{}~{}\mathcal{B}\textit{et}(\alpha+1,n_{m}) (7)

In order to sample α𝛼\alpha, we first sample 𝒙𝒙\boldsymbol{x} by a sequence of m𝑚m beta distributions according to Eq (7), conditioned on the current value of α𝛼\alpha and 𝒏𝒏\boldsymbol{n}. Then, given these values of 𝒙𝒙\boldsymbol{x}, we sample a new value of α𝛼\alpha from a mixture of gammas defined in Eq (5), conditional on the newly sampled 𝒙𝒙\boldsymbol{x}, with weights defined in Eq (6). In the latter step, we simply select an 𝒊∈2M𝒊superscript2𝑀\boldsymbol{i}\in 2^{M} according to the probability density ρ𝒊subscript𝜌𝒊\rho_{\boldsymbol{i}} and then sample a value from the corresponding gamma distribution.

Unfortunately, in all but trivial cases, M𝑀M is large and so computing ρ𝒊subscript𝜌𝒊\rho_{\boldsymbol{i}} directly for all such 𝒊𝒊\boldsymbol{i} requires an exponential amount of time (in M𝑀M). Thus, instead of computing the 𝝆𝝆\boldsymbol{\rho}s directly, we sample for them, effectively computing the constant Z𝑍Z though standard MCMC techniques. To perform the actual sampling from 2Msuperscript2𝑀2^{M}, we employ a Gibbs sampler. Each iteration of the Gibbs sampler cycles through each of the M𝑀M values of 𝒊𝒊\boldsymbol{i} and replaces imsubscript𝑖𝑚i_{m} with a new value, sampled according to its posterior, conditional on 𝒊−m=⟨il​ | ​1≤l≤M,l≠m⟩subscript𝒊𝑚inner-productsubscript𝑖𝑙 formulae-sequence 1𝑙𝑀𝑙𝑚\boldsymbol{i}_{-m}=\langle i_{l}\textrm{~{}}\arrowvert\textrm{~{}}1\leq l\leq M,~{}l\neq m\rangle. The derivation of this posterior is straightforward:

im=1​ | ​𝒊−msubscript𝑖𝑚conditional1  subscript𝒊𝑚\displaystyle i_{m}=1\textrm{~{}}\arrowvert\textrm{~{}}\boldsymbol{i}_{-m} =\displaystyle= a^+∑m′≠mima^+∑m′≠mim+nm​b^^𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝑚′𝑚subscript𝑖𝑚^𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝑚′𝑚subscript𝑖𝑚subscript𝑛𝑚^𝑏\displaystyle\frac{\hat{a}+\sum_{m^{\prime}\neq m}i_{m}}{\hat{a}+\sum_{m^{\prime}\neq m}i_{m}+n_{m}\hat{b}} (8)

Putting it all together, we sample a new value of α𝛼\alpha by first sampling a vector 𝒙𝒙\boldsymbol{x}, where each xmsubscript𝑥𝑚x_{m} is sampled according to Eq (7). Then, we sample R𝑅R-many 𝒊(r)superscript𝒊𝑟\boldsymbol{i}^{(r)}s using the Gibbs sampler with update given by Eq (8); finally selecting one of the 𝒊(r)superscript𝒊𝑟\boldsymbol{i}^{(r)} according to its empirical density. Finally, given this 𝒊𝒊\boldsymbol{i} and the xmsubscript𝑥𝑚x_{m}s, we sample a new value for α𝛼\alpha by a gamma distribution according to Eq (5). We have found that for modest M<100𝑀100M<100, nm<1000subscript𝑛𝑚1000n_{m}<1000 and km<500subscript𝑘𝑚500k_{m}<500, such a chain converges in roughly 50 iterations. In practice, we run it for 200 iterations to be safe.
